notes:
1. Aquifers

An aquifer is an underground layer of water-bearing permeable rock, rock fractures, or unconsolidated materials (gravel, sand, or silt). Groundwater can be extracted using a water well.

  • Unconfined Aquifer: An aquifer whose upper water surface (water table) is at atmospheric pressure, and thus is able to rise and fall.
  • Confined Aquifer: An aquifer that is overlain by a relatively impermeable layer of rock or clay (an aquitard or confining layer). The water in a confined aquifer is under pressure.

2. Darcy's Law

Groundwater flow is governed by Darcy's Law, which states that the discharge rate ($Q$) is proportional to the hydraulic gradient ($i$) and the hydraulic conductivity ($K$).

$$ Q = KiA $$
  • $Q$: Volumetric flow rate (m³/s).
  • $K$: Hydraulic conductivity, a property of the soil that describes the ease with which water can move through it (m/s).
  • $i$: Hydraulic gradient, the slope of the water table or potentiometric surface. It is dimensionless ($i = \Delta h / L$).
  • $A$: The cross-sectional area through which the water flows (m²).

The average flow velocity, or Darcy velocity, is $v = Q/A = Ki$.

solvedExamples.question: An aquifer in which the water is under pressure between two impermeable layers is called:
solvedExamples.explanation: A confined aquifer is 'sandwiched' between two confining layers (aquitards), which causes the water within it to be under pressure. When a well penetrates a confined aquifer, the water level will rise above the top of the aquifer.

solvedExamples.question: The water level is measured in two observation wells 200 m apart. The head is 55 m in one well and 50 m in the other. The aquifer has a hydraulic conductivity of 10 m/day. What is the Darcy velocity of the groundwater flow between the wells?
solvedExamples.explanation: First, calculate the hydraulic gradient: $i = \Delta h / L = (55 \text{ m} - 50 \text{ m}) / 200 \text{ m} = 5 / 200 = 0.025$. Then, use Darcy's Law for velocity: $v = Ki = (10 \text{ m/day})(0.025) = 0.25$ m/day.
